Name: Laura Gerber
Title/Role: QLD Minister for Youth Justice and Victim Support (also Minister for Corrective Services)
Relevance/How They Can Support: As the state minister responsible for youth justice, she can directly influence reforms and champion initiatives for rehabilitating youth.

Name: Amanda Camm
Title/Role: QLD Minister for Child Safety and Prevention of Domestic and Family Violence
Relevance/How They Can Support: Oversees child protection and wellbeing; her support can ensure at-risk youth receive the care and intervention needed to keep them out of the justice system.

Name: Fiona Simpson
Title/Role: QLD Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships (and Multiculturalism)
Relevance/How They Can Support: Key figure in Aboriginal affairs; can advocate for culturally appropriate youth justice approaches to reduce Indigenous overrepresentation in the system.

Name: Michael Berkman
Title/Role: Greens MP (Queensland Parliament) and justice reform advocate
Relevance/How They Can Support: Outspoken critic of punitive youth law changes; highlights human rights concerns and pushes for evidence-based approaches (e.g. opposing “adult crime, adult time” laws).

Name: Hylton Quail
Relevance/How They Can Support: Condemned harsh conditions in youth detention (Banksia Hill) and has used his platform to demand better treatment and reform for detained youth.

Name: Denis Reynolds
Title/Role: Former President, Children’s Court of WA (retired)
Relevance/How They Can Support: Veteran judge who described WA’s youth detention conditions as “child abuse,” urging a Royal Commission into juvenile justice failings.

Name: John Robertson
Title/Role: Former President, Children’s Court of QLD; Chair, Sentencing Advisory Council (Qld)
Relevance/How They Can Support: Publicly refutes the idea of a youth crime wave and warns that over-punitive reactions will only criminalise more kids – he advocates for evidence-based, rehabilitative reforms.

Name: Peter Johnstone
Relevance/How They Can Support: Proponent of restorative justice for Indigenous youth; led efforts to expand the Youth Koori Court to better rehabilitate Aboriginal young offenders through culturally adapted practices.

Name: Keenan Mundine
Title/Role: Co-founder, Inside Out Aboriginal Justice Consultancy; former youth prisoner
Relevance/How They Can Support: Draws on his incarceration as a youth to champion community-led solutions and justice reinvestment; even took his advocacy to the United Nations to urge better treatment of Indigenous youth.

Name: Dylan Voller
Title/Role: Youth justice advocate; former detainee at Don Dale (NT)
Relevance/How They Can Support: Became the face of abuse in youth detention after a 2016 exposé – now actively speaks out for reform, including raising the age of criminal responsibility and improving detention conditions.

Name: Dujuan Hoosan
Title/Role: Aboriginal youth advocate from NT (featured in In My Blood It Runs)
Relevance/How They Can Support: At just 12, he addressed the UN Human Rights Council urging Australia to raise the age of criminal responsibility from 10 to 14, sharing a child’s perspective on harsh justice policies.

Name: Nicola Forrest
Relevance/How They Can Support: Leads major philanthropic investments in early childhood and youth programs (e.g. the Thrive by Five initiative), aiming to tackle root causes of youth offending through prevention and community support.

Name: Professor Kristy Muir
Relevance/How They Can Support: Heads one of Australia’s largest philanthropic funds focused on breaking cycles of disadvantage; supports innovative initiatives (like justice reinvestment projects) to keep young people out of prison.

Name: Matthew Cox
Relevance/How They Can Support: Guides significant philanthropic support for young Queenslanders’ education and wellbeing; drives place-based partnerships to address factors that contribute to youth offending.
